Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Award: Human Adaptation To Environmental Variability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Little is known about the sensitivity of marine mammal species and their human predators to environmental changes. IÃ±upiaq people of the northwest Alaskan coast today rely on marine mammal hunting for a large portion of their subsistence as they have for millennia, but it is uncertain how observed and expected changes in the marine ecosystem might affect future food security. Archaeology is uniquely situated to provide perspective on this problem because it can consider human activity over long periods of time, and investigate how past changes affected marine mammals and their human hunters. This research will examine if and how environmental variability in the Arctic over the past 2,000 years affected marine mammals that in turn influenced human hunting patterns. This project will compare evidence for changes in marine conditions and their timing to variation in human diet based on the remains of animal bones from archaeological sites. This research will also contribute long-term baseline data enabling broader understanding of marine ecological dynamics in the Arctic. Results of the study will be incorporated into National Park Service public media and curriculum that is shared with northwest Alaska schools.

Hunter-gatherers generally focus on capturing resources that provide the highest energy return compared to energy expended. The diet of northwest Alaskan peoples has varied over the past two millennia, but it is unclear if these shifts are in any way linked to the health of marine mammals, on which contemporary communities rely. It is expected that variations in marine mammal health, brought about by changes in the marine environment, should drive these shifts. To evaluate this claim, the co-PI will identify and tally animal remains to asses changes in human diet over the study period. The marine environment will be reconstructed by measuring isotopes of carbon and nitrogen present in archaeological marine mammal bones throughout the same period. The analysis is complemented by an existing radiocarbon chronology that will be augmented where needed to ensure tight control over the ages of analyzed samples. By comparing the timing of changes in human dietary preference to changes in the marine environment, this study will assess the influence of marine health on the diets of coastal Alaskans. Results of this research will provide time-depth and broader context to studies of current environmental changes and their impact on communities reliant on marine mammal hunting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Little is known about the sensitivity of Arctic marine mammal species and their human predators to environmental change. Iñupiaq people of the northwest Alaskan coast today rely on marine mammal hunting for a large portion of their diet as they have for millennia, but it is uncertain how changes in the marine ecosystem might affect future food security. The past can provide insight. This research explored how residents of northwest Alaska reacted to environmental change in the past by combining osteological and isotopic analyses of marine mammal bones from Late Holocene archaeological sites located across Cape Krusenstern National Monument. Hypotheses framing the research focused on marine environmental change and human subsistence. Primary outcomes include an improved chronology of zooarchaeological assemblages, new insights into the feeding ecology of pre-modern pinnipeds, and contributions to long-term ecological baselines of the marine ecosystem. Initial results indicate ecological changes occurred over the past two millenia, but traditional subsistence pursuits were resilient and continued through documented environmental shifts.

We added 15 radiocarbon dates to the Cape Krusenstern site database, increasing the chronological resolution of both the site complex and the isotope analyses conducted for the project. This allowed marine environmental proxies to be compared directly to archaeological results. These new dates also add to the number of radiocarbon ages available regionally, allowing for increased precision in interpretive analyses. Carbon and nitrogen isotope results generated by this research help us better understand the life-history and trophic ecology of prehistoric marine mammals around the western Arctic. Based on preliminary analyses, isotopic results suggest a significant change in ecological dynamics in the marine system affecting ringed seals (Pusa hispida). Carbon isotopes indicate that the mode of primary production was consistent from 1800 to 600 years ago, while the nitrogen isotopes suggest significant differences in ringed seal feeding ecology through time. Seals apparently ate quite low on the food chain in the early 1st millennium AD, and even lower around AD 1000. Six hundred years ago, seals ate higher on the food chain, near modern levels. This century scale variability implies real changes in seal ecosystem dynamics that likely affected human subsistence opportunities. These changes could relate to bottom-up climate drivers and/or changes in competition for food with other marine predators. These changes may be reflected in the increased diversity of resources harvested in the post-1000 AD interval.

Species and skeletal element identification was performed on over 7000 specimens. Osteological analyses such as age classification and skeletal element measurements were made on subsamples of the larger dataset. Seals were an invariant and dominant component of the human diet during the past 1800 years, regardless of changes in seal feeding habits. The data reveal an even greater dietary reliance on ringed seal than previously thought, despite isotopic proxies indicating seals, at times, ate at a lower trophic level than expected. Fish are more abundant in human diets in later times, perhaps as a result of the development and intensification of net-fishing technologies.  While this confirms prior expectations, the timing of this increase is earlier than thought by 100-200 years. This result necessitates a reevaluation of the chronology and patterns of social and settlement changes in the late prehistoric period.

Broader impacts include public education and community engagement in Alaska Native communities around Kotzebue Sound. An outreach visit to Kotzebue, Alaska in January of 2018 included a public lecture and a visit to Kotzebue High School’s Iñupiaq studies class with activities and discussion in hypothesis testing, artifact identification, ethnographic data collection, and interdisciplinarity. Classroom activities were built around educational materials co-developed by the co-PI during a previous project. This project contributed directly to the professional training of a Ph.D. student.


Last Modified: 05/07/2018
Modified by: Adam K Freeburg

Iñupiaq people of the northwest Alaskan coast today rely on marine mammal hunting for a large portion of their diet as they have for millennia, but it is uncertain how changes in the marine ecosystem might affect future food security. The past can provide insight. Initial results indicate ecological changes occurred over the past two millenia, but traditional subsistence pursuits were resilient and continued through documented environmental shifts.
